text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

BRIAN KENNY: For nine
seasons, Michael Scott

and his team at Dunder Mifflin's
Scranton regional office

entertained viewers
with their squirm

inducing take on an
office culture that was,

by any standard,
highly dysfunctional.

Debuting in the US in 2005,
this reboot of a British sitcom

immediately struck a
chord with audiences.

Because, let's
face it, we can all
relate at least a little bit.

And since we spent about one
third of our lives at work,

the culture and physical
environment of the workplace
really matter.

It's a topic that gets
a lot of attention.

Amazon currently
lists over 9,000 books
on workplace culture.

Google lists over 64,000
academic and scientific

articles on the physical
and mental impact of office
lighting and furniture.

And it's not just
an academic concern.

PWC's 2017 report on the
workforce of the future

revealed that
millennials and Gen Z

place company culture
and environment very high

on the list when
considering jobs.
They care deeply.
And they set the bar high.

Today, we'll hear from professor
Jeffrey Rayport about his case
entitled, WeWork.

I'm your host, Brian Kenny, and
you're listening to Cold Call.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

SPEAKER 1: So we were
all sitting there
in the classroom--

SPEAKER 2: Professor
walks in and--

SPEAKER 3: And they look
up, and you know its coming.

SPEAKER 4: Oh, the
dreaded cold call.

BRIAN KENNY: Jeffrey Rayport
is an expert in online media

and e-commerce with a focus
on new business opportunities

enabled by emerging
digital technologies.

Jeffrey, thanks for
joining me today.

JEFFREY RAYPORT: It's a
pleasure to be here, Brian.
Thank you.

BRIAN KENNY: It's your second
spin in the Cold Call seat,

so you've got the drill
down pretty much, I guess.
JEFFREY RAYPORT: Absolutely.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

And that's the
first time I've ever

been able to mention Dunder
Mifflin in an intro so,
I had a little fun with that.

JEFFREY RAYPORT:
That was very nice.
Talk about television trivia.
Our listeners should know.
BRIAN KENNY: There you go.

So I'm going to ask you
to start the way I always
ask folks to start.

Can you tell me, who's the
protagonist in this case
and what's on their mind?

JEFFREY RAYPORT: So the
protagonist of this case

is Miguel McKelvey,
who many people

will know as one of the
two co-founders of WeWork.

His partner, Adam Neumann, is
the more visible of the two.

Adam is CEO and Miguel just
until the time of the case,

is the architect and
chief creative officer
as well as co-founder of WeWork.

And the case presents
him in a new role--
chief culture officer.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

And for those who
don't know out there

what WeWork is, can you
just describe what they do?

JEFFREY RAYPORT:
WeWork is the leader

in a category that in
the real estate industry

is referred to as this
serviced office leasing market.
BRIAN KENNY: That's catchy.
JEFFREY RAYPORT: It is catchy.

And it's actually
been a moribund sector
for a very long time.

People will know it from the
dominant player in the category
called Regus, now called IWG.

Regus is the rentor
of short term leased

office space for scenarios,
if you'll forgive me,

a little like the
television show
you referenced at the front end.

Meaning these are gray,
formica laden spaces
with indoor, outdoor carpeting.

And they're pretty generic
corporate environments.
IWG is the leader in the space.
WeWork is number two.

But WeWork is really
known as the pioneer

in a new category that is
referred to as coworking.

Coworking is an interesting
term coined in 2005

by a software engineer named
Brad Newberg, simply referring

to the idea of
independent workers
sitting in the same place.
That's the idea.
BRIAN KENNY: OK.

And this is a little bit off the
beaten path from your research
expertise in digital.

And so how did you hear about
WeWork and what prompted
you to write this case?

JEFFREY RAYPORT: Well,
it's a great question.

I met Miguel McKelvey
at a tech conference

down in New York City,
actually in Brooklyn,
that I was moderating.

And he and I did a
little fireside chat.

We started talking about the
scaling challenges at WeWork.

And he mentioned his new role
as chief culture officer.

I pulled him aside afterwards, I
thought he was a wonderful guy,

and I said, listen, I've
never met anyone who
was a chief culture officer.

What in the world
does that mean?

And that was the genesis
of this case study.
BRIAN KENNY: OK, great.

And I think people
are really going
to enjoy hearing about WeWork.

I had heard of
them, but I wasn't
aware of their meteoric rise.

So really interesting
challenges they're facing.

So the co-founders have
interesting backgrounds,

and I'm curious
if you can tell us

how their life experiences
kind of led them down this path
and to the concept for WeWork.

JEFFREY RAYPORT: Well,
Adam and Miguel could not
be two more different guys.

But thinking about
their life stories,

they're eerily
running in parallel
until the day they met.

So Miguel was born out in
Oregon, in Eugene Oregon.

And he grew up not with one
mom, but with a bunch of mothers

as he referred to
them in a commune.

This is a bunch of women,
essentially a matriarchy,

and they ran a big
collective family

and he essentially
helped earn the

keep because they started a
newspaper called The Eugene
Weekly.

And he learned a lot about
business and entrepreneurship

watching his mother
and the other mothers
get this off the ground.

He went to the
University of Oregon,

was trained as an architect,
got out of school,

and went to Japan just to
kind of think about life.

Wound up starting a business
and English as a second language
website called English Baby.

And after raising venture
dollars, he came back to the US

and thought, maybe it was
time to work as an architect.

He wound up at a firm,
having moved to New York,

in Brooklyn that
had just done a deal

to build out stores for a
brand that became iconic--
that is American Apparel.

And over the next
five or six years,

Miguel was party as an
architect, a designer,

a general contractor,
and a business guy

to helping them open 180
retail stores across the United
States.

So switch to the other universe,
Adam Neumann grew up in Israel.

Spent five years as an officer
in the Israeli Defense Force.
Came to New York.
Started a couple businesses.

One of which was
designer shoes for women

that had spike heels that
could collapse and turn them
into flats.
That failed.
Kind of interesting.

BRIAN KENNY: Exactly
what you would

expect a former officer of
the Israeli army to get into.

JEFFREY RAYPORT:
Well, those of you

who've seen pictures
of Adam Neumann,

he's a fairly glamorous, long
haired guy whose sister is

a model-- a supermodel,
or was at the time.

And so he saw her changing shoes
frantically for photo shoots

and thought, I can do something
to solve this problem.

He went on from there
to baby clothing.

Some will know the
old brand, Crawlers,

which were baby pajamas with
kneepads and elbow pads.

That got into the major
department stores,
but Adam was still restless.

At the point when he and Miguel
met each other in Brooklyn,

in the late aughts,
they started a business

called Green Desk, which was
an eco-friendly coworking
environment.

They did it with a landlord
who owned the building
that they started it in.

And the two of them were
walking in Brooklyn one night

looked at each other
and said, you know what?

This landlord is only
interested in making

coworking spaces in the
buildings he already owns.

We have a vision that this
could change the world of work
on a global basis.

We'll never scale
with this construct.

So they sold Green
Desk to the landlord

and took the few million dollars
of proceeds from that sale

and plowed them into the
first WeWork, which opened
in lower Manhattan in 2010.

BRIAN KENNY: And what does
a WeWork space look and feel
like?
What's special about it?

JEFFREY RAYPORT: That
is a great question.

Because if somebody dropped
you in one WeWork space

and you looked around, you
would see a bunch of open space

with closed offices with
glass partitions-- floor
to ceiling glass.
Lots of plants.
Lots of eco-friendly details.
Lots of exposed brick.

Exposed HVAC systems
on the ceiling.

In the common area
you would find a way
to have an espresso coffee.
There's always beer on tap.
There are a bunch of tables.
There's stylish music playing.

There interestingly
hip environments,

but they are optimized
for the world of work.
But work in a new paradigm.

That is, you know, we
think about if you were

a new card carrying member
of a lower Manhattan

office for Google
or Facebook you,

would expect it to
be open, loft space,

there'd be enclosed
spaces you would go
into for private conversations.

But in general,
that is the new way

in which the world works
in the tech sector.

And WeWork has attempted
to create, if you will,

a multi-tenant platform
for that kind of concept.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

So this is really appealing, I
mentioned it in the intro, to,

the millennials and
the Gen Z and the way

that they want to go to work
in the kind of environment
they want to be in.
JEFFREY RAYPORT: Hugely so.

And many Fortune 500 companies
view WeWork environments

as a way to attract
millennial talent.

So about 25% of the occupants
of WeWork spaces at the time

we wrote the case, which is
spring of 2018-- quite recent.

They had, at that time,
about 210,000 members.

And about 25% of
those 210,000 are

people who are part of
Fortune 500 workforces

where somebody said, gee,
we're General Electric

and we have a bunch of
people sitting in Springfield
and productivity is way down.

What if we airlifted 120 of
them and put them into a WeWork?

Let's perform a kind of classic
Hawthorne experiment type
thing.

Let's put them in a
different environment,

pay attention to
them a different way,
and see if productivity goes up.

The Fortune 500,
Fortune 1000 companies

are voting with
their feet by putting

elements of their workforce
there to see what happens.

They're finding very
favorable results,

and hence, they're putting
more folks in there.

So it started as something
that attracted, if you will,

small, medium business startup
folks-- millennial talent.

It's now become a much
broader demographic swath
of the working world.

BRIAN KENNY: And so I've got
a two part question then.

Because I'm curious, in
your view, how disruptive

this is to commercial
real estate as we know it,
or as it's been.

Because it sounds like
it's pretty disruptive.

And as they bring people
into these places,

how does it work for the
brand of the firms that
are moving people in?

Because I would imagine
that millennials and Gen Z

are flocking to
places that they feel
are supporting them in this way.

JEFFREY RAYPORT: It's a
fascinating development

in the world of
commercial real estate.

To give you a sense
of the scale of it,

the current estimate there
are about 14,000 coworking

spaces in the world at
the time of the case.

Obviously, only
a few have scaled

to the visibility, of say,
on IWG if you count that.

Or a WeWork or WeWork's closest
competitor, a new venture

backed relatively young
firm called Knotel.

But the scale of this kind
of working environment
is stunning.

And to give you a statistics,
there are today, in Manhattan ,

itself, one borough
of New York City,

there are more than 50
WeWork coworking spaces.
BRIAN KENNY: Wow.

JEFFREY RAYPORT: In London,
the current estimate

is between 18% and 19%
of all commercial office
space in the city of London--

I mean London, not the
financial district,

is now dedicated to coworking
either tenants or landlords.

So it's a very big deal
to be able to field

this alternative kind
of environment for work.

And as a result, yes, companies
that situate themselves

in these kinds of
environments, which

tend to be smaller
and medium sized

who are not at the point where
they are a scaled venture that

can produce an environment
bespoke for themselves,

it is much easier to rent
office space as a service,

so to speak, than it
is to either build it,

or if you are a big
legacy organization where

your offices look kind of
like The Office on television,

then the question is, how
do you wave a magic wand

and get a big change
for a group of people
within your workforce?

One way is to put them
into a space like this.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

And the case gets into, sort
of, the rapid growth of WeWork.

I mean they grew at an
extraordinarily fast pace
from their founding in 2005.

But just the coworking thing
turns out not to be enough.

You've got two
serial entrepreneurs.

Apparently they're still
thinking about other ideas.

So can you talk a
little bit about some

of the ways in
which they started

to branch off of the WeWork
idea into other areas?
JEFFREY RAYPORT: Absolutely.

To your point about how
fast this has grown,
the first WeWork opens in 2010.

By time we wrote the case in
2018, there were 242 of them.

Abridge, 50 plus were
in New York City.
But they were span the globe.

Almost a quarter million
people in these spaces.

So it's already a
significant phenomenon

funded by almost unprecedented
levels of venture investment.

At the time we wrote the
case, they had a $20 billion

valuation, having raised
$8 and 1/2 billion

worth of capital to
fuel this growth.

Having that much
capital has allowed

them to begin to think
about adjacencies.

The most important of them is
something called WeLive, which
is a residential operation.
There two of them.
One in the New York area.
One down in DC.

That, at the time of the case,
that allow people, essentially,

to check into a complete
life that is, in many cases,

co-located with WeWork
coworking spaces.

But co-living spaces sound just
like what the name implies.

They are usually
multiple bedroom suites.
You can live with roommates.
You can live on your own.

But there are a bunch of
communal areas and services

that are typically associated
even with high end condominium
developments.

Common kitchens,
catering, game spaces,
workspaces, and so forth.

BRIAN KENNY: Gets back a little
bit to Miguel's upbringing

if you think about growing
up in that commune and type
environment, right?
JEFFREY RAYPORT: Absolutely.

And actually I should say
that the fascinating thing

about Miguel and Adam Neumann,
just back to your original

question, how did these
guys have commonality?

Adam Neumann, of course,
grew up in Israel.

He spent a great deal of his
life living on a kibbutz.
He was living in a commune.
So I sort of look at these guys.

They could not present
more differently,

but they are brothers
from a different mother,
as the millennials like to say.

In having, yes, this kind of
shared experience of living
and working.

And, of course,
it won't surprise

you to hear that they also
have created something called

We Labs, which is essentially
an incubator like space
for startups.

WeGrow, a project of Adam
Newman's wife, Rebecca,

which is about creating
a new form of education
for early stage humans--

otherwise known as
pre-school and grade school.

So there are a lot of
things that they're
doing to experiment.

But, of course, the main event
is in the coworking spaces
themselves.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

JEFFREY RAYPORT: You asked,
Brian, just the question of,

what is their position
in the industry?

what's fascinating is, back
to our discussion of who
the comps are--

if IWG is the comp, IWG
has about a 21% share

of this serviced
office leasing market.

WeWork, apples for apples,
has about a 4.2% market share.
Now here's the funny thing.

You've got 20% share and you
got 4% share, for round numbers.

And yet, IWG is a
public company that

has a market cap, at the time of
the case, of around $2 billion.

WeWork, at the time a case,
has a private market valuation
of around $20 billion dollars.

So now you ask,
what is the value

of each additional share point
to WeWork carved out of IWG?

Well, when a share point
moves from IWG to WeWork,
it's 50 times more valuable.
BRIAN KENNY: Wow.

JEFFREY RAYPORT:
So it's remarkable

that they've taken
a space that is

a pretty generic
commoditized business,

and found a way to
inject enormous value.

BRIAN KENNY: Do you think
they can sustain it?

I mean, are they
trying to do too much?

The brand, by the
way, works beautifully
across all those platforms.
JEFFREY RAYPORT: It does.
BRIAN KENNY: But is it too much?

And this gets into the heart
of the case, which is really

about, you know, how
do you scale a culture

to be able to support
this kind of rapid growth?

JEFFREY RAYPORT:
Interestingly, Adam Neumann

himself says, look, a $20
billion valuation company
doing commercial office space--
are you kidding me?

I mean his view is there
is no way you could
argue for that kind of value.

And his point, which is
consistent with Miguel's view

on the business,
is that it is what

Adam refers to as their culture
and their spirituality which
is driving the valuation.

Another way of looking
at it is to say

that, you know, in
technology terms,

everyone is familiar
with PCs as hardware.

And the operating system that
sits on top of the hardware,
essentially to help it run--

the operating system
is in itself a platform

for a bunch of software
applications like the Microsoft

productivity suite
that we all know of--
Word, PowerPoint, Excel.

And then, of course, on
top of those applications

sit what we refer
these days to as apps.

Kind of lightweight
things like macros
that you build on top of Excel.

Miguel and Adam's point
is that office space

is the commoditized platform,
the personal computer hardware,

that today nobody can sell and
make any-- other than Apple,

nobody can actually
generate any margin
from the sales of hardware.

It used to be that Microsoft
could build a fortune selling
an operating system.

Well that's become
largely generic.

And in the case
of mobile devices,

it's not as if Apple or Google
make money off iOS or Android
as operating systems.

So the money is moving up
the stack from hardware

to operating system to
software applications
to lightweight apps.

And their argument is
that some combination

of community, of
spirituality, of culture

is in the OS to
applications layer that

is where all the value in
commercial real estate going
forward will come from.

BRIAN KENNY: Herein lies another
business opportunity for them
which we'll get to in a minute.

But how have they thought about
applying that theory to WeWork?

JEFFREY RAYPORT: So the
interesting challenge

for Adam, and
especially Miguel--

Miguel is the one who's
undertaken this at WeWork--

is to say, look, if this
is where the magic is--

call it valuation-- call
it anything you want--

but this is what is driving
the meaning of the brand,

the brand's meaning to the
communities of people who live

inside WeWorks, the thing
that makes it sought after,

not just among small SMB
type businesses or startups,
but also Fortune 500--

if it's the culture,
then actually,

that's $15, $20 billion
worth of cultural value.

We need to figure
out what it is.

So the thing that
caught my attention

in those initial
conversations with Miguel

is that we were talking
about the role of culture
in startups.
And it's a funny thing.

In general, startup culture is
associated with the founders.

It's often associated
with a creation myth

around the early days of how
the business got off the ground.

And in general,
people lament the fact

that as businesses
grow and scale,
that culture gets diluted.

People often talk in
kind of elegiac ways

about the early days
and when it was just
us and 20 other people.

And now it's 2000 people
and we've lost our soul.

And Miguel said to me,
is like, I completely
disagree with that.
I said, well, what do you mean?

He said, culture is not
a game of nostalgia.
Culture is a tool.

It's an instrument you use
to drive a business to scale.

And so you have to constantly
design and redesign

culture for each
additional level

up that the organization makes
in scale or reach or impact
or value.

BRIAN KENNY: So how is
he doing that at WeWork?

JEFFREY RAYPORT: The
fascinating thing about Miguel

is that he is,
first and foremost,
an architect and a designer.

And in the same way that one
would think that if you wanted

to determine, say, the
culture of a workspace,

it might have a lot to
do with whether space

was open or closed, whether
it has shared desks,

whether the walls were vibrant
or they were bare brick,

or whether there was music
playing or not playing
or whatever.

His point of view
is that culture

is susceptible to
design in the same way.

And that actually
designing space

is one significant
lever on culture.

But that there are a
number of other levers

that look more
organizational or managerial.

And all of them are susceptible
to management control.

Put it a different way,
what they've evolved

is something that they
call the Culture Operating
System at WeWork--
or the Culture OS for short.

Let me quote to you the eight
pillars of the Culture Os
at WeWork.

I'll just read
them to you, Brian.
So they are purpose--
and that's the obvious.

Sort of, why do we matter
to ourselves in the world?

There's leadership,
which is, how

did the senior people
deliver on the purpose
of the organization?

There's space-- well we
were just talking about,
but it's not just office space.

It's the design of
the online community

and all of the other aspects
that define the space.

Citizenship, which
is, how to all of us

contribute to the
values of the community?

Connection-- building
relationships to one another.

Performance agility--
this is something--

a very interesting concept
Miguel originated where he's

essentially saying that
change on the inside

of the organization
is faster than change

on the outside of
the organization.

Meaning that you're proactive,
not reactive in the way
that you perform.
There's talent.

Obviously find good people,
grow them, et cetera.
And finally, platforms.

Sort of what are
the systems, tools,

et cetera that enable
the environment
and all the rest of it.

The reason I wanted to go
through those one by one

is, first of all, to give
you and our listeners

a sense of, OK, these are the
building blocks of the Culture
OS.

But also to say that what's
remarkable about that list

is there's not a
single word on it

that I've ever seen on a
list of corporate values.

My interpretation of this
is that things like passion

and integrity and teamwork and
excellence and commitment--

those are perfectly
useful descriptors
of cultural outputs.

But that our friend Miguel,
as a designer, was saying,

I get it that we
want those outputs.

But what I'm interested in
as a designer, as a manager,

as a leader is to figure
out, what are my levers?
What are the inputs?

How can I actually shape
the culture that I want?

So his point would be that, of
course you celebrate integrity
and teamwork and excellence.

But you've got to start
by serving the people who

are going to wind up forming the
teams, aspiring to excellence,
and exemplifying integrity.

His point being that
as opposed to this

being some mystical
thing that people

can engage in arm waving
about, it's actually
something very practical.

As opposed to taking it as
something that is an act of God

or nature that just
happened to us.

Our culture happened to us
because we were 2000 people

and suddenly we turned into a
different kind of organization.
He's saying, wait a second.
You can craft this.

You can make the
culture you want.

And because you're
making it to order,

you can make it to fit the
size and characteristics
of your organization.

BRIAN KENNY: I mean
it all makes sense.

And therein I guess
lies the other business

idea that Miguel has, being
a serial entrepreneur.

He's going to try and-- not
just make this work at WeWork,

but he thinks there
is a model that can be
replicated in other places too.

JEFFREY RAYPORT: You mean
by other geographies?

BRIAN KENNY: No, I actually
mean in other organizations.

One of the things that
the case alludes to

is that Miguel is thinking
about taking the show
on the road a little bit.
JEFFREY RAYPORT: Absolutely.

So I'm glad you're
focused on that.

So the presenting
issue in the case

is the question of whether
WeWork brings something
to market that they refer to--

PxWe, which is short
for Powered by We.

And, as you said, it's all part
of a very elegant brand family.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.
JEFFREY RAYPORT: All of this--

WeWork, WeLive,
WeGrow, Powered by We.

But the idea there
is that if, going

back to our hypothetical
example, GE takes 120 workers.

They put them into a
space in lower Manhattan.

120 workers turn out to
be three times as happy
and four times as productive.

And the question is, I
got 10,000 people back
where they came from.
What do I do for those 10,000?
So two choices.

One is take the 10,000 and
break them up into groups

and put them into the 50
WeWorks all over Manhattan.

But that's huge
amount of dislocation
and also, obviously, cost.

The alternative is to
turn to WeWork and say,

can you do, for my
workforce, in situ,

what you would have
done for them if they'd

moved their locus of work into
your coworking environment?

The question is, do you
bring a product or an offer
like this to market?

Miguel's view is that
this is completely

consistent with the
goals of the venture.

Does it mean that you give
up some element or control?
Be careful what you wish for.

BRIAN KENNY: Be careful
what you wish for.
Yeah.

JEFFREY RAYPORT: You might
get a consulting business.

The other side of it, though,
and this is what Miguel argues,

is that his mantra is that work
because it's your life-- better
be something that you love.

You've got to not
just like what you do.
You got to love what you do.

And even today
where WeWork is now

quarter million people
in those WeWork office

coworking environments,
that is obviously

a minuscule percentage
of all the people

who go to work every
day who get out of bed

and think about the commute,
think about the eight
